G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the acts and omissions giving rise to this action occurred in Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 89, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant's driver, as an employee or agent of Defendant, had a duty to exercise reasonable care under G.L. c. 89, § 14 and G.L. c. 90, § 14, including the duty to check for oncoming bicycles before opening a car door adjacent to a bike lane.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant's driver, as an employee or agent of Defendant, had a duty to exercise reasonable care under G.L. c. 89, § 14 and G.L. c. 90, § 14, including the duty to check for oncoming bicycles before opening a car door adjacent to a bike lane.

Gouin v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co..raw_text: Gouin v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co., 165 F.2d 449, 450 (1st Cir. 1948)
Gouin v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co..proposition: Defendant's duty to use reasonable care is well-established under Massachusetts law.

Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.raw_text: Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499-500 (1968)
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.proposition: Courts in Massachusetts have long held that violating a statute designed to protect the public, such as G.L. c. 89, § 14, constitutes evidence of negligence.
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that violation of a criminal statute is evidence of negligence and applies that principle to G.L. c. 138, § 69, a statute designed to protect the public. Although the cited statute in the case is not G.L. c. 89, § 14, the court articulates the general Massachusetts rule that violating such protective statutes is some evidence of negligence. Thus, it supports the broader proposition that violation of a public-safety statute constitutes evidence of negligence in Massachusetts tort law.
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “A violation of a criminal statute is some evidence of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp. 267 Mass. 501, 516. Baggs v. Hirschfield, 293 Mass. 1, 3. Falvey v. Hamelburg, 347 Mass. 430, 434.”

Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.raw_text: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.proposition: Courts in Massachusetts have long held that violating a statute designed to protect the public, such as G.L. c. 89, § 14, constitutes evidence of negligence.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.support_reasoning: The opinion passage deals with foreseeability, duty, and proximate cause in premises liability, not with statutory violations or G.L. c. 89, § 14. It does not discuss the effect of violating a statute as evidence of negligence or adopt any such rule. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that violating a public-safety statute like G.L. c. 89, § 14 constitutes evidence of negligence in Massachusetts.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner or proprietor is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons. ‘The test is “foreseeable harm.” … The underlying duty in every case, however, is to exercise the care which the circumstances reasonably require.’ Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 642 (1961). Based on the evidence presented, there could be no reasonable difference of opinion as to the improbability of the incident which occurred.”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: The principle of vicarious liability for an employer's negligence is well-established.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses and applies traditional respondeat superior principles and explicitly treats vicarious liability of an employer for an employee’s torts—here, medical malpractice—as a standard, established rule of agency law. The court emphasizes that once an employment relationship is shown, the employer is liable for torts within the scope of employment, and specifically notes that corporate liability for negligence of physician employees is “commonly recognized,” confirming the well-established nature of the doctrine.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment.… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.… Applying these principles, corporate liability for the negligence of physician employees is commonly recognized.”

Braman v. Worcester Consolidated St. Ry..raw_text: Braman v. Worcester Consolidated St. Ry. Co., 264 Mass. 240, 243 (1928)
Braman v. Worcester Consolidated St. Ry..proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that cyclists are entitled to the same protections under the law as other users of the road.
Braman v. Worcester Consolidated St. Ry..case_name: Eastern Advertising Co. v. Standard Nut Co.
Braman v. Worcester Consolidated St. Ry..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a contract dispute over payment for advertising services in peanuts and issues of rescission and agency authority. It does not discuss cyclists, roadway users, traffic law, or any principle about the legal protections afforded to cyclists. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts recognize cyclists as entitled to the same protections as other road users.

Gore v. Arbella Mut. Ins. Co., 77 Mass..raw_text: Gore v. Arbella Mut. Ins. Co., 77 Mass. App. Ct. 518, 522 (2010)
Gore v. Arbella Mut. Ins. Co., 77 Mass..proposition: The Defendant’s failure to properly monitor and train its drivers on the specific risks to cyclists constitutes actionable negligence, as recognized in *Gore v. Arbella Mut. Ins. Co.*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 518, 522 (2010).
Gore v. Arbella Mut. Ins. Co., 77 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns an insurer’s unfair claim settlement practices and violations of G.L. c. 93A and c. 176D, not a motor carrier’s or employer’s duty to monitor and train its drivers about risks to cyclists or any analogous duty of care. The opinion’s analysis focuses on the insurer’s duty to promptly and fairly settle claims and to inform its insured of settlement offers; it does not discuss training or supervision of drivers, cyclists, or negligence standards related to such conduct. Thus, citing this case for the proposition about failure to monitor and train drivers on cyclist risks is inaccurate and unsupported by the holding or reasoning.
Gore v. Arbella Mut. Ins. Co., 77 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The statutory scheme also recognizes that encouraging the prompt settlement of claims protects the insured. ‘The insurer has a duty to its insured. If it does not fulfill that duty, it may violate G. L. c. 176D, § 3(9), and be liable to its insured.’… In light of these principles, the judge did not err in concluding that Arbella had engaged in unfair settlement practices.”

Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 14 (1991.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were a foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s breach of duty, consistent with the precedent set in *Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 14 (1991).
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 14 (1991.support_reasoning: The case does not discuss or find that the plaintiffs’ injuries were a foreseeable consequence of a defendant’s breach; instead, it holds that the defendant parent owed no legal duty under these circumstances. The court expressly refuses to impose a duty on a parent who neither provides nor makes alcohol available, even if the parent knew minors would drink and might pose a risk of harm. Thus, Wallace v. Wilson is authority against, not for, the claimed foreseeability-based liability proposition.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 14 (1991.relevant_excerpt: “We reject the argument that a parent, who neither provides alcoholic beverages nor makes them available, owes a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise a party given by her minor child. We reach this conclusion even if [the defendant] knew or reasonably should have known that alcoholic beverages would be available. The defendant’s conduct did not create a risk of injury to the plaintiff for which we are prepared to say the common law should provide a remedy.… We continue to adhere to the rule expressed in Langemann, and we think that that rule should apply here.”

Commonwealth v. Galluccio, 11 Mass. App..raw_text: Commonwealth v. Galluccio, 11 Mass. App. Ct. 190, 191-92 (1981)
Commonwealth v. Galluccio, 11 Mass. App..proposition: This Court has further held that distraction, such as using a phone while driving or parking, constitutes negligence.
Commonwealth v. Galluccio, 11 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns warrantless entry, exigent circumstances, Fourth Amendment protections, and evidentiary issues in a drug case. It does not discuss driving, parking, distraction, phones, or negligence. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that distraction such as using a phone while driving or parking constitutes negligence.
Commonwealth v. Galluccio, 11 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: We, however, read the Payton case as proscribing, in the absence of exigent circumstances, any nonconsensual entry through the partly open door of Huffman’s apartment without a warrant, even though the officers had knowledge that a crime was probably there still in progress.

Dolan v. Suffolk Frank P. Morrissey Coff.raw_text: Dolan v. Suffolk Frank P. Morrissey Coffee Co., 322 Mass. 76, 78 (1947)
Dolan v. Suffolk Frank P. Morrissey Coff.proposition: Defendant’s broader duty of care to cyclists in proximity to its vehicles is recognized by Massachusetts law and caselaw.
Dolan v. Suffolk Frank P. Morrissey Coff.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns municipal tax assessment procedures and the authority of town assessors and the Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation regarding deductions and available funds. It does not involve motor vehicles, cyclists, or any duty of care in traffic or tort contexts. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a broader duty of care owed by defendants to cyclists under Massachusetts law.
Dolan v. Suffolk Frank P. Morrissey Coff.relevant_excerpt: The case is entirely about tax assessments and municipal finance; there is no discussion of vehicles, cyclists, or negligence duties, so no excerpt is relevant to the claimed proposition.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Prejudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
